issues.title: Dropdown not working
issues.body:
My rails version is 5.1.4 and `bootstrap-sass` version is 3.3.7.

Dropdown is working in Safari, but not on Chrome(version 63).

I tried the dummy rails under test directory, and I found its dropdown is not working in either of Safari and Chrome.

Though, alter the order of "jquery" and "bootstrap-sprockets" fix this problem but get more errors.

So, what's the solution?

issues.title: ejs < 2.5.5 security vulnerability
issues.body: There appears to be a security vulnerability in ejs < 2.5.5. Even though its a dev dependency the latest release of bootstrap-sass is using ~2.4.2. Just thought I'd flag that to you http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/101893

issues.title: bg classes?
inverted ceil() and floor() in make-row mixin
issues.body:
I just came across a minor issue while debugging another.

I think ceil() and floor() are inverted in the make-row mixin here.
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid.scss#L16

The rounded number will always be negative so the result will actually work the opposite way as it does in the col mixins here:
https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_grid-framework.scss#L16

In a nutshell the bug shifts the visible content 1px to the right if the grid-gutter-width is an odd number.

little example (first row broken, second default, third fixed):
https://codepen.io/quarkus/pen/oGydpW?editors=1100

Pretty hard to see as its just one pixel, but its noticable on the left edge of the cols

issues.title: @function theme-color function missing
issues.body: Is there a reason why the _functions.scss is missing? We have an Issue where another package is calling the theme-color function but unfortunately it cannot be found in bootstrap-sass package.

issues.title: form-control-focus mixin error
issues.body:
Hi,

I am getting error while using form-control-focus mixin:

Message:
    node_modules/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_forms.scss
Error: wrong number of arguments (2 for 1) for `box-shadow'
        on line 60 of node_modules/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/mixins/_forms.scss
\>\>     @include box-shadow(inset 0 1px 1px rgba(0,0,0,.075), 0 0 8px $color-rgba)
   -------------^

I didn't find any similar issue and not sure how do I create a test case for this.

I made a pull request with a fix (#1140)

--- 
node-sass	4.5.3	(Wrapper)	[JavaScript]
libsass  	3.5.0.beta.2	(Sass Compiler)	[C/C++]
Node.JS v8.4.0

issues.title: SASS's digits of numeric precision is changed
issues.body:
Starting with SASS 3.5.0, ten digits of numeric precision is default.
Please reflect this in your document.

[http://sass-lang.com/documentation/file.SASS_CHANGELOG.html](url)

issues.title: Sass Compile Fails Due to Semicolon
issues.body:
grunt-contrib-sass failed to compile `assets/stylesheets/_bootstrap.sass` file. Logs;

```
Running "sass:dist" (sass) task
Verifying property sass.dist exists in config...OK
Files: others/sass/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.sass -> res/css/bootstrap.css
Options: style="compressed"
Command: sass others/sass/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.sass res/css/bootstrap.css --style=compressed
Error: Invalid @import: expected end of line, was ";".
        on line 8 of others/sass/bootstrap-sass/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.sass
  Use --trace for backtrace.
Warning: Exited with error code 65 Use --force to continue.
```

Oddly, I removed all the semicolons at the end of each line and it worked like a charm.

## Environment

 - grunt-contrib-sass 1.0.0
 - sass 3.4.21
 - bootstrap-sass 3.3.7

pull_requests.title: Update ejs version because of potential security vulnerability
pull_requests.body: The ejs has a known moderate severity security vulnerability in version range `< 2.5.5` and should be updated

pull_requests.title: Remove extra parens
pull_requests.body:
As of `"node-sass": "3.3"`, checked that it is parsing correctly. Made a gist to demonstrate:

https://www.sassmeister.com/gist/fc77f10337d940ea3a1015b5e524dee8

pull_requests.title: Update README.md
pull_requests.body:
I came across an error message in the browser after installing Bootstrap using Rails 5.1.3 and realised the jquery gem is not added by default with the newer version of Rails thus ```gem jquery-rails``` needs to be written manually in the Gemfile 

(Using Google Chrome V60)

pull_requests.title: Split @font-face declaration into a separate file
pull_requests.body: Since it would be in a separate file, you can choose not to `@import` it by hand and provide the declaration by yourself. Our use case is to drop EOT and SVG formats and put it in line with other `@font-face`s using mixins.

pull_requests.title: add refer to add gem for rails 5.1+
Added a tweak for the responsive-visibility mixin for the col tag.
pull_requests.body: We had a problem with columns width when we used the visible-* on col tag because the display type was set to block. We simply added the default display value for col.

issue_comments.body: Thanks for this, I'll take a look at it later.

Okay, all looks good, apart from the duplicate variables.css.scss thing.

The gemspec needs altering to include the generators in the built gem but that's a 1 line fix.

I'll pull this into a topic branch on my repo and sort those out, then I'll merge it into master.

Cheers.

Sorry for the late response, I've had a crazy week with essays and my uni application.

@grk's method should work pretty well for now. Creating an app-side `variables.css.scss` is something should be addressed in #1, but it appears `sass-rails` imports from the current directory if the file exists _before_ looking through the asset paths, meaning it will use the gem's copy of `variables.css.scss` with the default helper manifest. I think this won't be so much of an issue if I create a new manifest that will live in `app/assets` on `rake bootstrap:variables`, (something like `boostrap-custom.css.scss`) since it should (hopefully) look in `app/assets` before going to the gem file, but I haven't had time this week to check it out properly.
Merged, thanks.

I've been following that issue for some time and wondering what was up.

I'll merge it in a second, and probably push a minor v. update later today, along with sorting #1 out. (I did really want to to follow Bootstrap's versioning, but it leaves me with so much inflexibility)
Yeah, like I said, I'll break from Bootstraps versioning and push an update in the next few hours.
I've just pushed 1.3.1 to Rubygems

I'm not sure about merging this in yet, since I have been updating bootstrap-sass as new versions of Bootstrap have been released. Pulling in just the javascript changes now means that I'll have a master branch that has the CSS of 1.3.0 and the javascript of somewhere between 1.3.0 and a future HEAD.

While I will update the javascripts to their latest versions when a new version of Bootstrap is released, pulling these changes now means I'll either have a project that's neither here nor there, or I'll have to keep up with Bootstrap's master branch. 

My current approach to updates appears worked well so far, and I don't see myself attempting to keep up with Bootstrap master, so for now I would suggest you point Bundler at your own git repository and use that.

The current version of bootstrap-sass has the CSS & JS from the v1.3.0 tag.

[https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/tree/v1.3.0](https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/tree/v1.3.0)

Are these javascripts from the gh-pages branch, or master?

If they are from the gh-pages branch, then my apologies, I probably will merge them in. I was unaware that the publicly documented javascripts had changed - I thought there was just changes on master.

Bad form from Bootstrap's maintainers though - if you're going to tag a release, don't change the code after you've tagged it. :-1:
Merged. I'll push out 1.3.2 in a few minutes.
Yeah, I'm hoping to get it done this afternoon, I'm just trying to work out the most efficient way of updating.

@grk's method for configuring variables in bootstrap-sass will be recommended in the new documentation site (when I get it finished).

Whether it is with a generator or not is something I still haven't decided.
CSS conversion is done, going to update the javascripts and push 1.4.0.

go get her:

https://rubygems.org/gems/bootstrap-sass
Oop, I'll push 1.4.1 later today.

This is why I need to keep hacking on my automagic converter.

Thanks.
I can only presume that this is an issue with sass-rails, since bootstrap-sass doesn't alter the @import method.

But the file is an SCSS file, rather than a ruby file, so it's not something that would be interpreted by ruby.

Anyhow, it does increase readability so I'll probably merge it in anyway.

commit_comments.body: Of course, the sha reference in the commit is a complete lie and should actually be twitter/bootstrap/33a969dd0c.

ah bollocks, yes.

It only affects responsive layouts though, right?
fixed

You want to adjust the number of columns for responsive? I don't think Bootstrap by default 'allows' that.

I've just defined it as per Bootstrap - [here](https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/commit/1fa3c2519ddc82a3b3520047f18d65c8d7b0ca82#L14R500), Bootstrap will use the global `$gridColumns` value, so if you override that then you will have `x` columns throughout your application.

I think the width is adjustable, I'm away from my laptop so I'm going off the top of my head, but $gridColumnWidth in combination with $gridColumns (and $gridGutterWidth, where appropriate) should change the overall width of the site, however currently the responsive layouts are not adjustable through variables as per upstream. I guess this is something that should be addressed in further releases of Bootstrap, there's not much point in being able change the default grid if the responsive grid is not easily changed without moving away from the 'sensible' defaults. 

Sent from my iPad

On 2 Apr 2012, at 08:36, Wolf Vollprechtreply@reply.github.com wrote:

> When digging through the code a little more i noticed that the width is fixed, so sorry on my behalf.
> 
> Still i think it'd be awesome to adjust the number of columns and instead of generating a fixed-width grid do somethink like `940px/$columnCount`. But anyway, I was able to fix it for my purposes. 
> Thanks for your quick response!
> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/commit/1fa3c2519ddc82a3b3520047f18d65c8d7b0ca82#commitcomment-1160751
I removed it because it was pretty hastily thrown together and didn't _exactly_ work as a fluid column should. I can put it back in, though.
Massive fail on the commit message, but yeah.

review_comments.body: All the variables are suffixed by `!default` so that we can override them before the file is imported.
Sass < 3.2 doesn't support variables in media breakpoints, so this hasn't been 'upgraded' yet.
Is this meant to be committed?
Do we add a dependency on sass ~> 3.2 as well? sass-rails only adds a dependency for >= 3.1.10, and compass only specifies ~> 3.1, which won't force users to use 3.2.
Should we keep this file as `@import "responsive"`? Would stop apps from breaking with this update, and thrown in a warning or similar to notify that the file has changed.
Ah okay, hadn't seen that.
Sass appears to have [@warn](http://sass-lang.com/docs/yardoc/file.SASS_CHANGELOG.html#_directive), although it is off by default in Rails. :unamused:

@m5o @trisweb - Bootstrap defines this as taking a value [0,100] when the CSS spec takes a value [0,1]. We redefined this (#52) to the CSS spec since it makes the most sense, and to fix potential conflicts with Compass. Thoughts? I've gotten used to the [0,1] behaviour.

The only issue with animations would be if someone legitimately wanted [0..0.01] opacity. It doesn't sort the underlying issue of the deviation though.

It made sense at the time because I assumed Bootstrap would move to the [0..1] opacity anyway - passing a decimal value [0..100] as a parameter to opacity doesn't even make sense. Obviously I guess that's not going to happen now. Better we move in line with what upstream says, even if - semantically and spec wise - it is wrong.

commit_comments.body: Awesome!  Great work...just wanted to say thanks.

Please revert this since it breaks the layout.

$gridGutterWidth is passed to the mixin and is different than the global one

Haven't you forgotten something here?

I wanted to adjust gridColums, so I suggest "gridColumnWidth" and "gridGutterWidth" there.
Thanks for the awesome work of porting!

When digging through the code a little more i noticed that the width is fixed, so sorry on my behalf.

Still i think it'd be awesome to adjust the number of columns and instead of generating a fixed-width grid do somethink like `940px/$columnCount`. But anyway, I was able to fix it for my purposes. 
Thanks for your quick response!

Why 

``` css
.row-fluid > .spanX
```

instead of

``` css
.row-fluid .spanX
```

like found in the [original Less code](https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/blob/master/less/mixins.less#L623)?

Fine! Didn't see the change.
Thanks :)
Okay, looks like [they removed](https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/commit/37745cd8997bdc1d0bb21c276a7aa671bb018eed) it. Sorry, I had an outdated reference version.
was this mixing deleted by mistake or should I use another one?
can you please publish them gem? thanks!

I have to just say that this is brilliant!  I was just going to huff and puff and tear the bootstrap css down to make it useful in Sass myself, and I was hesitant to try your method.  But I am glad I did!!  It is a nice little gem.. Thank you.

I think that maintaining the functionality that goes along with being able to set this variable is more important than supporting sass 3.1. Can this decision be revisited now that sas 3.2 has been out for a few months?

No worries—pull #246 addresses this and adds back support for the variable. It should be merged and released within the week.

See https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/pull/246/files#L55L8
If you can wait til after the 1st, then yes, I'd be happy to.
Please use 2.3.1.0 for the time being. Thank you.
Ah sorry—misunderstood. Try `gem uninstall bootstrap-sass` and bundle again.

review_comments.body:
The patch is used in the script `update-bootstrap.sh` to make updating to the next release automated—yep, it is intended to be committed.

As I said in the pull, I'm open to other methods, but I think automating the procedure you'd otherwise be doing manually is a good solution.
Ah you're right - I thought sass-rails specified 3.2. Thanks, I'll add the dep now.

Good solution. I like the name change to the simpler 'responsive' but definitely want to maintain backward compatibility.

Any ideas on how to alert/warn that the name has changed? Can we do that during compilation or something?

Ah darn. Well I've done the `@warn` anyway just in case, and provided a comment. We can keep the file around indefinitely, or choose to break backward compatibility and force people to deal with it. I'm really fine either way.
It should actually be `fade-in` (with a dash) - `fade_in` is the function name but a dash is used within the SCSS itself.

Well that's a conundrum. Is there a bug open at twitter/bootstrap? Is there a particular reason you know of that bootstrap chooses that range?

That would cause upgrade compatibility issues if people used the mixin elsewhere, how likely is that?

What are the specific conflicts with Compass here?
Note: my personal preference is we keep consistency with the upstream bootstrap code to make upgrades (and following the global bootstrap docs) easier...
Sorry, just read #52. Yeah this is a hard one...

No, in fact that's the problem. It just indicates that it expects a value in the range of 0-100, which it then converts to a decimal 0-1 for the standard CSS rule.

@thomas-mcdonald is saying he prefers the mixin to take the same value as the CSS rule, requiring no conversion.

Would that cause any issues with animations (if any use the mixin?) that go from 0-100 (might cause an early "flash" of 100% opacity as it hits 1) or is this mixin fairly well restricted to static bootstrap elements?

FWIW I agree with @mmoss for the long term, and would prefer if we switch to being consistent with bootstrap immediately if possible. @m5o's solution makes me scared of unforeseen consequences if we go with it, and the existing 0-1 range makes me fear mistakes made due to inconsistency.

I'm still not sure how to solve the compass issue...

Agreed. The current mixin is straight from upstream, so we can just keep as-is.

Is there a good way to prevent this from affecting Compass users? Can we provide a workaround for them at least in documentation?
Thanks, will fix here as well.

I believe this would be slightly more correct as:

``` ruby
if defined?(::Rails)
```

Also we'd prefer the comment above the line instead of inline. Thanks!

notifications@github.comwrote:

> Ah sorry—misunderstood. Try gem uninstall bootstrap-sass and bundle again.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/commit/abf20dae81b894fc5e03aaa006887265254277d1#commitcomment-3119514
> .

Just in case this helps someone...

I followed the above advice (ran `gem uninstall bootstrap-sass`, changed the line in Gemfile to `gem 'bootstrap-sass', '~> 2.3.1.0'`, ran `bundle` again)... but the bundle command still said "Could not find bootstrap-sass-2.3.1.1 in any of the sources".

I think this is because it was still listed as `2.3.1.1` in my Gemfile.lock. So I completely removed the `gem 'bootstrap-sass', '~> 2.3.1.0'` line from my Gemfile, ran `bundle` (this removed all trace of bootstrap-sass from my Gemfile.lock), then put the line back in the Gemfile, then ran `bundle` again. This time it worked.

correct me if i'm wrong, but should the `opacity: $opacity / 100` already solve this
I'm also not happy with this special if-condition. I also agree with @mmoss. If someone use this combination the opacity fix must be done manually. Maybe with a advice on an new wiki page?
`inculde` - I've found a typo and will update the upstream tonight.

sorry for the delay - now we are ready

jlong/sass-twitter-bootstrap#56

Maybe I misunderstand, but if this is supposed to be a port of bootstrap for use in a Sass environment, then shouldn't it simply follow what the framework already does in LESS? I'm a huge fan of following specifications and normalizing mixins and whatnot to match them, but this seems really counter intuitive. I've already had at least one instance of a designer running afoul by following other Twitter Bootstrap resources when using this gem.

I understand the conundrum given that this may conflict with Compass, but not everyone using Twitter Bootstrap uses Compass (in fact the company I work for has at least one project that uses your gem as an alternative to Compass).

+1 for following what Bootstrap does, given that this is, well, supposed to be... 

> ...bootstrap for Sass, ready to roll
